user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_FindRetvalConfig:
```c
UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_Stub_FindRetvalConfig(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubEntryPtr;

    StubEntryPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED);
    if (StubEntryPtr != NULL)
    {
        /*
         * The counter on a deferred retval config indicates the number of times it should
         * be skipped/not used.   Decrement the counter now, and if it is not yet 0, do not
         * return this yet, and go to a fallback - which could either be a constant value
         * configuration, or the default fallback of 0.
         *
         * By definition, deferred retvals are only used once and then deleted.
         */
        --StubEntryPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter;

        if (StubEntryPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter > 0)
        {
            StubEntryPtr = NULL;
        }
    }

    if (StubEntryPtr == NULL)
    {
        StubEntryPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT);
        if (StubEntryPtr != NULL)
        {
            /*
             * the counter on a constant retval config will track the number of
             * times the value was actually used, so it is incremented here.  Unlike
             * deferred retval configs, these values may be used multiple times during
             * a test.
             */
            ++StubEntryPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter;
        }
    }

    return StubEntryPtr;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code fragments were identified in this function. Reasoning:

- The initial call to UT_GetStubEntry may legitimately return either NULL or non-NULL, so both the outer if (StubEntryPtr != NULL) body and the subsequent if (StubEntryPtr == NULL) branch are potentially reachable at runtime.
- Within the first branch, decrementing StubEntryPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter can produce either a value > 0 or <= 0 at runtime, so both outcomes of the inner if (StubEntryPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter > 0) (setting StubEntryPtr = NULL) and falling through (keeping StubEntryPtr) are reachable depending on the counter value.
- After that, the second lookup via UT_GetStubEntry(…, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT) is only executed when StubEntryPtr == NULL, which can occur either because the initial lookup returned NULL or because the counter logic set it to NULL; that branch and its inner increment are therefore reachable.
- There is no code following a return, no labels/gotos that cannot be reached, no constant conditional expressions that would make branches dead, and no constructs that imply compile-time unreachable statements.

Because every conditional and statement in the function can be reached under some valid runtime condition, there are no fragments here that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
